channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Debate Over Identity and Race Asks, Are African-Americans ‘Black’ or ‘black’?
item.description: The push to capitalize black to refer to African-Americans is far more than a typographical change.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: The prominence of the Black Lives Matter movement has helped reignite the debate over the capitalization of the word black. Above, protests continued last week following the killing by the police of Rayshard Brooks in Atlanta.

item.title: Many Latinos Couldn’t Stay Home. Now Virus Cases Are Soaring in their Communities.
item.description: Rates of coronavirus infection among Latinos have risen rapidly across the United States.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Thomas Fuller, Anjali Singhvi and Juliette Love
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Shawn Hubler/The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re the ones who are out in the work force,” said Cynthia Orozco, a 20-year-old high school tutor and civil engineering major at California State University, Fresno, who contracted the virus along with her mother, Graciela Ramirez, a machine operator at Ruiz Foods in Dinuba, Calif.

item.title: As Virus Surges, Younger People Account for ‘Disturbing’ Number of Cases
item.description: People in their 20s, 30s and 40s account for a growing proportion of the cases in many places, raising fears that asymptomatic young people are helping to fuel the virus’s spread.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Swimmers at the beach on Thursday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The median age of Floridians testing positive for the coronavirus has dropped from 65 in March to 35 now, officials said.

item.title: Texas Governor Greg Abbott Pauses Reopening
item.description: A growing number of states are pausing plans to reopen, amid rising case counts. But Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said shutting back down was the “last thing we want to do.”
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asia Anderson, 25, monitors the line at a drive-through coronavirus testing site at United Memorial Medical Center in Houston.

item.title: House Fails to Override Trump’s Veto Limiting Student Loan Debt Relief
item.description: Stringent new rules by Education Secretary Betsy DeVos are set to take effect on July 1 after the attempt to reverse them was defeated.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos’s changes raised the bar for borrower relief claims, requiring applicants to individually prove that a school knowingly misled them.

item.title: Iraq Raids Iranian-Backed Militia Accused of Attacking U.S. Forces
item.description: Iraqi forces detained 14 members of the group, Khataib Hezbollah, to send a message that “no one is above the law.”
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers surveying the launch site of a rocket attack in January that killed an American contractor on a military base near Kirkuk. The United States blamed the Khataib Hezbollah militia for the attack.

item.title: Russia Secretly Offered Afghan Militants Bounties to Kill U.S. Troops, Intelligence Says
item.description: The Trump administration has been deliberating for months about what to do about a stunning intelligence assessment.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt and Michael Schwirtz
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: American troops in Afghanistan have been the target of some Taliban operations backed by Russia, intelligence officials found.

item.title: Going Up? Not So Fast: Strict New Rules to Govern Elevator Culture
item.description: Small, crowded, enclosed spaces are petri dishes for the coronavirus. But in urban office buildings, elevators are a necessity, so companies are wrestling with how to make them safer.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two employees of Boston Properties demonstrated proper safe distancing in an elevator at the Prudential Center in Boston.

item.title: ‘Through Art, I Hope That We Can Make One Tulsa’
item.description: Talking with two organizers of the movement to reclaim the long-ignored history of Black Wall Street and the Greenwood district’s achievements.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.media:credit: Chris Creese for The New York Times
item.media:description: Quraysh Ali Lansana, left, a poet and educator, and Jerica Wortham, project manager of the Greenwood Art Project, are among those trying to make sure the history of Tulsa, Okla., and Black Wall Street isn’t lost.

item.title: YouTube Personality Jenna Marbles Apologizes for Blackface Video
item.description: Jenna Mourey said she was ending her channel, which has more than 20 million subscribers, because of videos from 2011 of her impersonating Nicki Minaj and rapping lyrics about Asians.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Taylor Lorenz
item.media:credit: Stephanie Diani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The YouTube personality Jenna Mourey has been making videos for over a decade under the name Jenna Marbles. She apologized for several videos Thursday.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Valerie Solanas, Radical Feminist Who Shot Andy Warhol
item.description: She made daring arguments in “SCUM Manifesto,” her case for a world without men. But her legacy as a writer and thinker was overshadowed by one violent act.
item.dc:creator: Bonnie Wertheim
item.media:credit: Fred W. McDarrah/Getty Images
item.media:description: Valerie Solanas in the offices of The Village Voice in 1967, the year she published “SCUM Manifesto,” which was, in part, a call to arms for the coalition she was forming, the Society for Cutting Up Men.

item.title: Lockdowns Tamed Road Traffic. Here’s How Cities Aim to Keep It Down.
item.description: Officials are trying to prevent a return to urban gridlock and pollution as residents begin to travel again.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Kham/Reuters
item.media:description: Rush hour in Hanoi, Vietnam, last month as the country relaxed its nationwide lockdown.

item.title: How Progressive Candidates of Color Are Building Winning Coalitions
item.description: Candidates like Charles Booker and Jamaal Bowman are bringing together liberal white voters and voters of color, a dynamic seen this week in races in Kentucky and New York.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Pat Mcdonogh/Louisville Courier Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Charles Booker, a Democratic Senate candidate in Kentucky, prepared to vote at the Kentucky Expo Center in Louisville.

item.title: A Step Toward 51
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: J. David Ake/Associated Press
item.media:description: Washington at daybreak.

item.title: A DNA Mix-Up Involving a Washing Machine Kept a Man in Jail for 3 Years
item.description: The Louisiana case highlights how prosecutors and crime labs withhold key documents from defense lawyers, keeping some defendants in custody for months or years.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:credit: Joseph Vidrine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roy Verret at his home in Jeanerette, La., with the washing machine that contributed to his murder charge.

item.title: The Great Wonders Beyond the Great Reef
item.description: A recent expedition to the inky depths of the Coral Sea revealed an unknown world of creatures and geologic features.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad

item.title: Joe Biden's VP Pick: Here's What Voters Think
item.description: A large majority of voters say race should not be a factor in his decision, and none of the best-known candidates has emerged as a favorite.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at a news conference on Thursday in Lancaster, Pa.

item.title: These Top Democrats Go Further Than Biden on Diverting Police Funds
item.description: Interviews with superdelegates and members of a Biden-Sanders task force found near-unanimous sentiment for redirecting money away from policing, with positions beyond what Joseph R. Biden Jr. has proposed.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Ryan Christopher Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York police officers at a protest this month. Of 54 Democratic officials surveyed, only four said they opposed shifting funds away from law enforcement agencies.

item.title: Can a Co-Working Space Go Online? It Can in a Pandemic
item.description: After the lockdown, the owner of Honey Space for Moms had such success going virtual that she is making bigger plans.
item.dc:creator: Amy Haimerl
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brooke Miller, the owner of Honey Space for Moms in Ferndale, Mich., moved her business online after she had to close her physical space in March.

item.title: Could Doomsday Bunkers Become the New Normal?
item.description: When we were told to stay inside our homes, a portion of the population quietly went below ground.
item.dc:creator: Mira Ptacin

item.title: These Girls Are Leading Black Lives Matter Protests
item.description: Like legions of Black women before them, these four young activists are building a better tomorrow.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Bennett
item.media:credit: John G Mabanglo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Tiana Day, 17, of San Ramon, Calif., led a march across the Golden Gate Bridge.

item.title: The Post-Coronavirus Cruise? Not Ready to Sail
item.description: Data shows that there were far more cases of Covid-19 on cruise ships than have been reported, but the companies and the C.D.C. have yet to establish how the boats can come back.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A no sail order from the C.D.C. has kept Pier 90, part of the Manhattan Cruise Terminal, empty for months.

item.title: Live Stock Market Tracker: Fed’s Dividend Cap Hits Banks
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Trump Administration Asks Supreme Court to Strike Down Affordable Care Act
item.description: If successful, the move would permanently end the health insurance program popularly known as Obamacare and wipe out coverage for as many as 23 million Americans.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: The case is by far the most serious challenge to date for the 10-year-old health care law, President Barack Obama’s signature domestic achievement.

item.title: House Passes Sweeping Policing Bill Targeting Racial Bias and Use of Force
item.description: Democrats’ legislation would institute significant changes to the rules that govern how police officers operate, but it is doomed in the Republican-led Senate.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Thursday said that the vote served as a pledge to the American public: “Never again.”

item.title: Carlos Ingram Lopez Death in Tucson: Another Video and Police on the Defensive
item.description: A city with a relatively progressive image and reform-minded police is grappling with a brutal death in police custody — and why it took so long to become public.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners gathered in Tucson on Thursday night for a vigil for Carlos Ingram Lopez, a Latino man who was killed in April while in police custody.

item.title: Five Months After Celebrating the Economy in Wisconsin, Trump Returns to a Different Place
item.description: At a shipyard on Lake Michigan, the president played up the economic benefits of a new Navy contract.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on Thursday in Marinette, Wisc. He returned to a state whose economy has been ravaged by the coronavirus shutdown, with an unemployment rate that has soared to just above 14 percent.

item.title: Coronavirus Rising in Florida, Arizona, California and Texas: What We Know
item.description: Updates on the surges in Texas, California, Arizona and Florida.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: Russian Criminal Group Finds New Target: Americans Working at Home
item.description: A hacking group calling itself Evil Corp., indicted in December, has shown up in corporate networks with sophisticated ransomware. American officials worry election infrastructure could be next.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum/Getty Images
item.media:description: Law enforcement officials announcing warrants for the arrests of Russian hackers associated with the group Evil Corp. at the Department of Justice in December.

item.title: Police Groups Wield Strong Influence in Congress, Resisting the Strictest Reforms
item.description: Law enforcement groups, which have donated generously to members of both political parties, have dictated the terms of the debate on an overhaul, prodding lawmakers to reject the toughest measures.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Anthony Geathers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Law enforcement groups have been successful through a persistent influence campaign of lobbying, campaign contributions and endorsements.

item.title: ‘It’s a Pandemic, Stupid’
item.description: We asked Tom Frieden, the former C.D.C. director, for some advice. It’s not all doom and gloom.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images

item.title: Here’s What You Need to Know About Elijah McClain’s Death
item.description: Mr. McClain died days after he was detained by the police last summer. His death has come to occupy a central place in Colorado’s fast-moving debate over police reform.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Tompkins

item.title: Trump Family Will Ask Second Court to Stop Publication of Tell-All Book
item.description: A Queens County, N.Y., judge said his court lacked jurisdiction in the case.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
item.category: Too Much And Never Enough: How My Family Created the World's Most Dangerous Man (Book)
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald Trump during an Address to Young Americans in Phoenix, Az., on Tuesday.

item.title: In Norway, Gymgoers Avoid Infections as Virus Recedes
item.description: In an unusual experiment, researchers found no coronavirus infections among thousands of people allowed to return to their gyms.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Kyrre Lien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Goril Bjerkan, of Baerum, Norway, went to the gym three or four times a week while participating in the study. “I suspect it was more risky to visit the shopping center than to visit the gym,” she said.

item.title: Disgraced Lobbyist Jack Abramoff Headed Back to Jail
item.description: Mr. Abramoff became the first person charged with violating a law that was amended in response to his previous criminal offenses.
item.dc:creator: Nathaniel Popper
item.media:credit: Charles Dharapak/Associated Press
item.media:description: Jack Abramoff, a former lobbyist who was convicted on charges of fraud, corruption and conspiracy, will be returning to jail.

item.title: Still Reeling From Oil Plunge, Texas Faces New Threat: Surge in Virus Cases
item.description: Businesses were reopening in recent weeks and oil prices had climbed north of $40 a barrel before coronavirus infections accelerated in the state.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A recent rally in oil prices had given energy executives in Texas hope that a recovery was at hand. Now they are not so sure.

item.title: Senate Panel Moves to Empower Justice Dept. Watchdog Over Barr’s Objections
item.description: Attorneys general have long sought to stop a proposed expansion of the authority of the department’s independent inspector general.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner, Nicholas Fandos and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Democrats in Congress have accused Attorney General William P. Barr of abusing his authority and using the Justice Department to benefit President Trump.
